did.unittitle: Center for Russian and East European Studies (University of Michigan) records
did.physloc: Portions of the collection are stored offsite; two days notice required for retrieval.
did.abstract: University of Michigan inter-disciplinary, area studies and resource center. Records relating to the administration of and the programs supported by the Center, including information on funding, courses, exchange programs, publicity, and affiliated activity. Also includes audio and video tapes of presentation and lectures.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The records were transferred by the Center for Russian and East European Studies (donor # 8615) in 1997.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: item, folder title, box no., Center for Russian and East European Studies (University of Michigan), Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: The Center for Russian and East European Studies (CREES) was the product of an expansion of area studies at the University of Michigan proposed by the College of Literature, Science and the Arts (LS&A) in 1959. LS&A appointed a committee chaired by anthropology professor William Schorger to develop the proposal. The committee recommended the creation of four new centers: the Center for Chinese Studies, the Center for Russian and East European Studies, the Center for South and Southeast Asian Studies, and the Center for Near and Middle Eastern Studies. In 1961, the University secured a grant from the Ford Foundation to carry out the proposal. CREES then became designated under the National Defense Education Act (NDEA) as a center for Slavic Language and an Area Center in 1959, by the United States Office of Education. Currently, CREES remains one of only twenty-two U.S. Department of Education supported resource centers for Eastern Europe, Russia, and Central Asia.

The major goal of CREES is "to prepare a new generation of outstanding academic experts and professionals for careers in or related to our region." The center works to accomplish this goal by offering many inter-disciplinary areas of study. The center draws faculty from a variety of other departments at the university to teach courses. A few of the subjects in which students can earn their degree from CREES are business, law, journalism and education. The researcher is invited to find current information about the center at its website, located at http://www.umich.edu/~iinet/crees/

scopecontent.p: The records for the Center for Russian and East European Studies (CREES) document an array of activities that the center has been involved with since its inception. Records from the 1980s to the 1990s make up the bulk of this record group. The documents reflect how the Center has grown and become active not just at the university level, but also at a global level. The financial, global, and business ties that CREES has worked hard to cultivate can be traced through this record group. The way those ties developed as well as the many other interests of the center will be of interest to researchers.
The records are arranged into seven series: Administrative Records, Exchange Programs, Funding, Alphabetical Files, Public Relations, Visual Material and Audio Material.

controlaccess.head: Subjects:
controlaccess.corpname: University of Michigan. Center for Russian and East European Studies.
controlaccess.subject: Soviet Union--Study and teaching.
Europe, Eastern--Study and teaching.

scopecontent.p: The series Administrative Records (1957-1997) consists of seven sub-series: Executive Committee, Inter-Center Council, Curriculum Materials, Orientation Materials, Advisory Council, Business Outreach, and Conference Materials. The sub-series Executive Committee documents the administration of CREES since it was founded. Of special interest to the researcher will be the history of the center. The Inter-Center Council was made up of representatives from all of the area centers. Its concern was how all of the centers should work together at the university. Curriculum Materials contains many bibliographies that were used for the courses that were taught. Orientation Materials are the records of a series of orientations that CREES held in conjunction with the Business School for people who were traveling to Russia or East European countries. They introduced people to a basic history of the country, the current political and social situation of the country and the culture of the country. Business Outreach and Advisory Council documents CREES's interest in making ties to the business community. Business Outreach covers the earlier, initial phase of the program, while Advisory Council is the official name that was given to the program once it became an established part of the center. The final sub-series, Conference Materials, documents the planning that went into many of the conferences that CREES sponsored.

scopecontent.p: Exchange Programs (1987-1997), the second series consists of three sub-series: American Collegiate Consortium (ACC), Graduate Exchange Programs and Miscellaneous Exchange Programs. Of special interest are the letters that some of the participants in the ACC wrote to CREES about the experiences that they were having in Russia. All of the correspondence with the universities in Russia are interesting because they show how closely the two sides had to work together to make the exchange program a success. The researcher should be warned that some of the correspondence is written in Russian with no available translation.

The series Funding (1961-1995) is composed of the proposals that CREES wrote to acquire funding for their programs. Of interest are the wide variety of sources to which CREES appealed, such as the federal government, the Corporation for Public Broadcasting and many private foundations. The wide variety of programs which CREES was is apparent.

scopecontent.p: The fourth series, Alphabetical Files (1974-1995), contains files arranged in alphabetical order by the subject to which they pertain. Many of the original subject headings that CREES used have been maintained. The bulk of the folders cover the time period of the early 1990s. The majority of folders deal with topics that do not appear anywhere else in the record group. Of note are the folders about the International Institute, especially about the development of the institute and plans for its new building.

did.unittitle: Center for Research Learning and Technology
School of Natural Resources and the Environment (SNRE)
United States Department of Education Meeting
Washington, D.C. U of M office

scopecontent.p: The series Public Relations (1961-1995) is composed of clippings and press releases that CREES had accumulated since its inception. They pertain to activities and interests that directly regarded CREES. Of special interest to the researcher are the clippings for "Michigan Briefing," held in 1986, which document the CREES conference focused on the evolving status the Soviet Union at the time.

The series Visual Material (ca. 1980s-1990s) contains video and cassette tapes of lectures given at the University of Michigan on various areas of research in Russian and East European Studies. In addition to these taped lectures, the researcher should pay special attention to the tapes of Russian television programs(in Russian). They contain images of Moscow and other areas of Russia. Another tape that may interest the researcher is the American Collegiate Consortium tape, which describes the undergraduate exchange program involving U-M and Russian students. There are no transcripts or translations for any of the video tapes.

scopecontent.p: The final series Audio Material includes both cassettes and micro-cassettes of lectures given by researchers in the field of Russian and East European Studies.
